moves.1. d4: Queen's pawn game. I prefer this move myself when playing white
moves.1... d5 2. c3: A strange and slightly passive move by white here. Transposes the game into the queens pawn variation of the Saragossa Opening, a rather uncommon opening.
moves.2... c5: Black attacks whites central d pawn.
moves.3. Nf3: Defending the d pawn and developing. Good move.
moves.3... Nc6: Black develops his knight as well eqalizing the fight for the center
moves.4. Qa4: White violates on of the basic opening principles by moving her queen out early. There is no strategic or tactical benefit for this opening violation
moves.4... Bd7: Black takes advantage of whites dubious queen advance and sets up a discovered attack on the white queen. White should now retreat the queen with a move like Qc2
moves.5. e4: e4 allows black to take advantage of the discovery on the queen...
moves.5... Nxd4: Whites response here should be Qd1
moves.6. Bb5: Bb5?? Hangs the bishop by moving it right into the line of fire from both black's knight and Bishop.
moves.6... Nxb5: Here, again, a possible discovered attack on the white queen. White needs to retreat her. Qc2 here is a good move
moves.7. g4: Dont have a clue what this move was really for...ignores the discovered attack that looms...
moves.7... Nxc3: Black's knight gets another "free" move and takes another pawn. The queen now under a double attack has to find a safe place to run. Qc2, once again will accomplish this.
moves.8... Qxa5: white loses the queen. Black now has a discoverd check, and a threat on the previously advanced pawn on g4
moves.9. Nxc3: White takes the knight, but pins her own. Black will be able to take advantage of this next move...
moves.9... d4: d4...attacks the pinned knight on c3
moves.11... Nf6: Black defends the bishop, but is eyeing the undefended pawn on e4. The pawn on e4 looks defended, but it's defender is pinned...
moves.12. Bg5: attacks the knight on f6, but hangs the pawn on e4
moves.12... Nxe4: Leaves the bishop but black is a queen and 4 pawns ahead and can afford to give back a bit of material for positional play. Black now triple attacks the pinned knight on c3
moves.13. O-O: White finaly unpins the knight, but is a little late...
moves.13... Nxc3 14. Nxg4 Ne2+: Black needs to save his knight...
moves.15. Kg2 Qb6: Really, Im just trying to get my queen to the other side of the d and c pawns, but Im doing so with threats along the way. Qb6 fits into that plan and threatens the pawn on b2 as well as a check on c6
moves.16... Qc6+: Black continues his plan, with check this time...
moves.17. f3: white blocks the check, but pins one of her few remaining pieces...
moves.17... d3: defends the knight and makes room for Nd4, going after that pinned pawn...
moves.18... c4: defends the passed d pawn. Blacks far advance connected pawns are going to be a problem for white...
moves.20. Re3: white sees the threat and defends...good one!
moves.20... e6: Black wants to get his last piece out. The threat now is Bxb4
moves.21. Rd2: whie misses the discovered attack and hangs the pawn on b4
moves.22. Rb2 Qd6: defends the bishop and places the queen behind the passed pawn that is no unstoppable without further sacrifice from white...
moves.23. h5: White is out of ideas? Nf2 can bring some help over to defend against the passer. Re4 would open the bishops defence of the d2 square...
moves.23... d2: Black takes advantage of his passed pawn. whites limited responses include Rb1 and Nf2 to attempt a stop...
moves.24... d1=Q 25. Kh3: white, possibly giving up? Moves into a mate in 2...
